organizations.name: Free Open Source Stories Digital Archive
organizations.description:
Free and Open Source Software has Changed The World

The free and open source software movement was started by individual technical visionaries who believed in digital freedom. It grew into a movement that has transformed software development, business, and modern society. Open source challenged and toppled the dominance of Windows, created a web browser that put people first, created the backbone of e-commerce, and revolutionized computing. It also invited the world to collaborate in ways it never had before. Today, there are over 50 publicly traded commercial open source software companies, all of whom, by definition, would not exist without the parallel coexistence of a given free and open source software technology.

The first generation of free and open source software developers, visionaries, and strategists — mostly baby boomers — is aging. As they step aside for a new generation, the personal stories of their contributions may be lost. We think it is crucial to collect and preserve this story of unrelated persons who made personal sacrifices, challenged the establishment, and changed how we envision technology and interact with the world.

A lot has been written about open source development and open source licensing — some practical, some polemical, some thought-provoking. But this project is not about the technology, or the theory, or the law. It is about the personal journeys of those who came together to revolutionize our modern technological world.

Most importantly, we need to capture how and why a generation self-organized to revolutionize the technology that runs our lives. Usually, changes come from the force of law, from political might, or from charismatic leaders. But sometimes — not often — it comes from people who come together spontaneously to build a dream. And that can happen even if those people are abrasive or have motives beyond the good of the community. We need to understand how and why this can happen, because the most profound changes are those that find their own place and time in a community that is born to embrace them.

metadata.title: Introduction
metadata.synopsis: Brian welcomes Daniel to the FOSSDA series as they begin to discuss open source.

metadata.title: Question 1
metadata.synopsis: Brian asks Daniel to share a little about himself and how his journey with open source and the ASF started.

metadata.title: Question 2
metadata.synopsis: Brian asks Daniel why he "kept going" when it came to open source and if being able to contribute hooked him into this field.

metadata.title: Question 3
metadata.synopsis: Brian asks Daniel if there are any things in general that appeal to him when working in open source

metadata.title: Question 4
metadata.synopsis: Brian asks Daniel if there are any things that interest him about open source that don't involve the ASF structure.

metadata.title: Question 5
metadata.synopsis: Brian asks Daniel if he had people who acted as mentors or early influencers during his early time in open source and the ASF.

metadata.title: Question 6
metadata.synopsis: Brian asks Daniel to talk about some of the other work he has done and other ways he likes to participate in the ASF.

metadata.title: Question 7
metadata.synopsis: Brian asks Daniel what the impact is that ASF has had on open source as an environement

metadata.title: Question 8
metadata.synopsis: Brian asks Daniel what advice he would give to someone who is just starting out with open source as far as what works and what does not work.

metadata.title: Question 9
metadata.synopsis: Brian asks Daniel what he would say to his descendants based on his current life and experiences he has had.

metadata.title: Outro
metadata.synopsis: Brian thanks Daniel for being letting him conduct the interview, then thanks the viewers and concludes the video.

lines.line: > The speaker introduces the Forza series of interviews, which focuses on the history of open source and the Apache Software Foundation (ASF). Brian Profit, the VP of Marketing and Publicity with Apache, welcomes Daniel Ruggieri, a member of the ASF and the httpd project management committee, to the interview.

metadata.title: Introduction to the Interview
metadata.synopsis: The speaker introduces the Forza series of interviews, which focuses on the history of open source and the Apache Software Foundation (ASF). Brian Profit, the VP of Marketing and Publicity with Apache, welcomes Daniel Ruggieri, a member of the ASF and the httpd project management committee, to the interview.

lines.line: > Daniel offers advice to newcomers to open source, suggesting they consider how they want to engage with projects and to research communities that align with their interests. He highlights the importance of finding a welcoming project and mentions his own efforts to teach open source at universities.

metadata.title: Guidance for Open Source Newcomers
metadata.synopsis: Daniel offers advice to newcomers to open source, suggesting they consider how they want to engage with projects and to research communities that align with their interests. He highlights the importance of finding a welcoming project and mentions his own efforts to teach open source at universities.

lines.line: > Daniel discusses the various ways he has contributed to the ASF, ranging from code contributions to presenting at conferences, participating in community development, and serving on the board of directors. He reflects on his growth within the ASF and the roles he has taken on to support the foundation.

metadata.title: Diverse Contributions to the ASF
metadata.synopsis: Daniel discusses the various ways he has contributed to the ASF, ranging from code contributions to presenting at conferences, participating in community development, and serving on the board of directors. He reflects on his growth within the ASF and the roles he has taken on to support the foundation.

lines.line: # Daniel Ruggieri's Entry into Open Source

> Daniel Ruggieri recounts his entry into the open source world, which began with his role as an internet operations web administrator. His initial engagement with Apache httpd led to submitting a patch that was accepted, marking the start of his deeper involvement with the ASF.

metadata.title: Daniel Ruggieri's Entry into Open Source
metadata.synopsis: Daniel Ruggieri recounts his entry into the open source world, which began with his role as an internet operations web administrator. His initial engagement with Apache httpd led to submitting a patch that was accepted, marking the start of his deeper involvement with the ASF.

lines.line: # The Allure of Open Source and ASF's Open Governance

> The speaker explains that the ability to contribute changes to open source software was a significant factor in his continued involvement. He emphasizes the importance of open governance within the ASF and how it contrasts with other models of open source projects that may be dominated by a single contributor or organization.

metadata.title: The Allure of Open Source and ASF's Open Governance
metadata.synopsis: The speaker explains that the ability to contribute changes to open source software was a significant factor in his continued involvement. He emphasizes the importance of open governance within the ASF and how it contrasts with other models of open source projects that may be dominated by a single contributor or organization.

lines.line: # ASF's Impact on the Open Source Ecosystem

> The speaker believes that the ASF has had an immeasurable impact on the open source ecosystem, citing its status as the largest software-producing entity and its role in making open source business-friendly. He credits the ASF with helping to mainstream open source and fostering the creation of new industries.

metadata.title: ASF's Impact on the Open Source Ecosystem
metadata.synopsis: The speaker believes that the ASF has had an immeasurable impact on the open source ecosystem, citing its status as the largest software-producing entity and its role in making open source business-friendly. He credits the ASF with helping to mainstream open source and fostering the creation of new industries.

lines.line: > Faced with the thought experiment of delivering a message to his future descendants, Daniel reflects on the rapid pace of change and the difficulty of predicting what will remain relevant in 100 years. He expresses a desire to provide context about the current state of the world and the history of open source to help future generations understand the past.

metadata.title: A Message to Future Generations
metadata.synopsis: Faced with the thought experiment of delivering a message to his future descendants, Daniel reflects on the rapid pace of change and the difficulty of predicting what will remain relevant in 100 years. He expresses a desire to provide context about the current state of the world and the history of open source to help future generations understand the past.

children.text: # Introduction to the Interview

> The speaker introduces the Forza series of interviews, which focuses on the history of open source and the Apache Software Foundation (ASF). Brian Profit, the VP of Marketing and Publicity with Apache, welcomes Daniel Ruggieri, a member of the ASF and the httpd project management committee, to the interview.
# Guidance for Open Source Newcomers

> Daniel offers advice to newcomers to open source, suggesting they consider how they want to engage with projects and to research communities that align with their interests. He highlights the importance of finding a welcoming project and mentions his own efforts to teach open source at universities.
# Diverse Contributions to the ASF

> Daniel discusses the various ways he has contributed to the ASF, ranging from code contributions to presenting at conferences, participating in community development, and serving on the board of directors. He reflects on his growth within the ASF and the roles he has taken on to support the foundation.
# Daniel Ruggieri's Entry into Open Source

> Daniel Ruggieri recounts his entry into the open source world, which began with his role as an internet operations web administrator. His initial engagement with Apache httpd led to submitting a patch that was accepted, marking the start of his deeper involvement with the ASF.
# The Allure of Open Source and ASF's Open Governance

> The speaker explains that the ability to contribute changes to open source software was a significant factor in his continued involvement. He emphasizes the importance of open governance within the ASF and how it contrasts with other models of open source projects that may be dominated by a single contributor or organization.
# ASF's Impact on the Open Source Ecosystem

> The speaker believes that the ASF has had an immeasurable impact on the open source ecosystem, citing its status as the largest software-producing entity and its role in making open source business-friendly. He credits the ASF with helping to mainstream open source and fostering the creation of new industries.
# A Message to Future Generations

> Faced with the thought experiment of delivering a message to his future descendants, Daniel reflects on the rapid pace of change and the difficulty of predicting what will remain relevant in 100 years. He expresses a desire to provide context about the current state of the world and the history of open source to help future generations understand the past.

story.description: In this series of interviews focusing on the Apache Software Foundation, ASF Member Daniel Ruggeri shares his journey to open source, which started with the ASF as a contributor to the httpd project. Today, Daniel imparts his open source wisdom at the university level (https://github.com/DRuggeri/OSSClass), and shares some of his experiences with us in this conversation.
story.title: FOSSDA: Exploring the Impact of the ASF with Daniel Ruggeri
